job_title: Hospital Services Specialist in Santa Rosa, CA
pros: Great team members, good pay, excellent benefits, great opportunities for growth
cons: It's a non-profit? Not really any cons, but non-profits can go through times of instability, although I have not had any issues.

job_title: Donor Outreach Coordinator in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great workplace, easy job, they're very lenient
cons: A little unorganized and the training was rushed

review_title: The Most unprofessional company I've worked for
pros: Great Pay for Phlebotomy Most of the people are fun
cons: The company doesn't care for Employee health you don't get a social life The company doesn't think ahead the hours are grueling The supervisors (whoever team you're on) can't take responsibility for their mistakes and they're clueless to what's embarrassing like having a personal talk in the same room of the break room where everyone can hear. I was lied to when I got hired saying the schedule was Monday-Thursday Uniform allowance doesn't become active for a long time. so you have to pay for your own the attendance system is the most ridiculous system thought of and has no mercy for people that have personal problems going on. all the equipment is so old and not taken care of it's embarrassing to show that to donors. the people who are in position of power are poorly picked and have no business being in that position. Over worked underpaid for the amount of work. I did things that weren't even in my job description, They made me work in the warehouse. That's not my job title. I felt like I had to fight just to stay at my position

job_title: Donor Center Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Strong sense of purpose, most coworkers are kind people
cons: Management will overwork you and drain every bit they can before you decide to leave. this is not the place to show initiative, you end up doing multiple people's jobs while supervisors sit on their phone.

review_title: Amazing mission, lots of room for improvement
pros: The job is very rewarding. Can directly see the impact made on the community and how your work is making a difference. Employees are friendly and happy to help one another.
cons: Pay and benefits are not commensurate with workload or responsibility level. Many employees work 50-60 hours per week with no overtime just to accomplish their job duties. Base pay is not a livable wage for single persons. There is no work life balance and management has said that if employees are not happy to be working 50+ hours/week and want more pay, that they should look for jobs elsewhere. Although the company states they are big in diversity and inclusion, there is a clear bias when it comes to age and disability status. There is also very little cultural diversity in many departments.

pros: flexible hours, opportunity to work OT, will hire just about anyone, good benefits, opportunity to advance quickly
cons: lazy/clueless management, no direction or support while transitioning to new computer system, so disorganized and lacks clear communication between departments, extreme staff shortage for over a year placing a huge burden on current staff, poor morale, everyone miserable that works here

pros: Most coworkers were great and friendly. Help each other out. Donors are nice and friendly and understanding. Work itself is great it’s fun just sticking all day. Centers are fun and chill overall unless it’s understaffed. Good compensation for travel.
cons: Travel is required outside of Sacramento and you are floated 2-3 times a week. Most of the time you stay in Sac but there are centers as far as Redding, Chico, Grass Valley, and Merced. They don’t tell you this when you are hired. Centers are understaffed and overbooked a lot and scheduling doesn’t care. Donors sometimes wait an hour to been seen.

job_title: Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: You can gain some experience you need
cons: It's not the best place to stay for long

job_title: Donor Center Technician in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Worked there for years. Good job great pay
cons: Management can be unfair and make you feel small

job_title: Donor Relations Specialist in Spokane, WA
pros: Best place to work. Great leadership.
cons: No cons that I van find.

job_title: Donor Care Specialist II in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great company to work for Good benefits Good pay Management has I proved a lot
cons: Schedule changes day to day which can be challenging.

pros: Almost a living wage, decent benefits.
cons: Worked nearly twice as many hours as they originally said they were going to give us. Constant condescending attitudes from supervisors. Terrible hours (10+ hour day, ending in the last evening with a 4am wake up for the next shift, etc). No transparency from management. No real growth opportunites.

pros: Everyone is committed to the mission of the organization which is raising funds to save lives by securing blood donations from the community and providing lifesaving blood components to hospital patients.
cons: People are still learning the name and how to pronounce it.

job_title: Hospital Services Technician in Mather, CA
pros: Being a part of the solution to help save lives every day was exciting and fulfilling. I had a lot of great coworkers who are friends for life. I learned a lot about myself and pushed my comfort levels to become a stronger person. The training was thorough and it is where I first discovered my passion for process improvement and working cross-functionally with other departments.
cons: It was a male dominated department where it was made clear to me that women should keep quiet and just do your job. That was very difficult and disheartening. I literally had a man tell me that it was a woman's job to be seen and not heard. Unfortunately when I brought this up and other issues, very little was done to address it and I noticed that my reviews became harsher. Ultimately, I got another opportunity and left. I hope things have changed for the better.

review_title: Worst Company I've Worked for (High Driver Turnover for a Reason)
pros: The benefits are top notch (once you're allowed to access your earned PTO after NINE months).
cons: - The upper management of drivers lacks all interpersonal, communication, organization, and general skills required - observing the lack of staff cohesiveness was inexcusable. - The schedule is erratic and inconsistent at best. They treat employees as "plug and play" pieces on a board without factoring in the human element; over 4 months in and I was still unsure what I was working week-to-week and often day-to-day, even around the holidays. For example, in a span of 7 days I had shifts of 4pm-12am, 6am-2pm, 10pm-6am. - Interoffice communication within the company is terrible, almost non-existent. - HR is unprofessionally callous and a one-way listener in handling questions and concerns. - With it being a union position (after 9 months of employment), way too much emphasis is placed on seniority; to the point where new hires whom are not yet unionized are expendable and not treated equally, nor as fairly, as union drivers. - After contracting COVID, I understandably had to follow company policy of 5 days quarantined, another 3 days until my fever subsided (also per company policy). then an additional 3 days where I wasn't allowed back until I received a physical from my doctor to be deemed fit to work due to shortness of breath (also per company policy). These 11 days counted against me as 'call-offs' since I was still in my probationary period and due to their "no-fault" policy. This incomprehensibly contradictory, unfair, and asinine policy does absolutely nothing to protect employees who are already working in a highly susceptible environment being in dozens of hospitals. - So don't plan on contracting COVID if you're a newer hire with Vitalant; or else their policy to protect employee and co-worker health is inexplicably negated by their attendance policy, even whilst having medical documentation.

pros: I like going to work knowing I am helping save lives every day. I never thought I would be in blood banking but I love the industry. The company wants you to grow as a person. I earned my Masters Degree while working with the company too. I've been able to travel and speak at national conferences. There are lots of different avenues you can take with this company. Pay, benefits and advancements are much better than many might think it would be.
cons: I left the company at one point to pursue other dreams and ended up coming back. I missed working for something so important and the great people that work at Vitalant. It is a nationwide organization. I wish we could make more decisions locally on some things but overall there are so many advantages to being a large company.

pros: Laid back environment, get paid while traveling to job site, no experience needed
cons: Schedule is not set or stable, a lot of physical labor moving equipment in and out of businesses that you travel to in all weather

review_title: Chaos is the order of the day.....
job_title: Lead Training Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Life-saving mission that touches communities across the nation.
cons: Organization has absolutely no concept of communication, holds a "quantity-over-quality" model as priority, does not understand the proper utility of organizational learning, viewing training as a solution to all problems rather than a resource for knowledge, supervisors default all performance issues to training rather than acknowledging the role they play in performance development and improvement, IT takes absolutely *zero* - and I mean ZERO - responsibility for delivering functional computers to new hires for remote orientation, resulting in costly disruptions that waste valuable time, money, and other resources.

review_title: Management and HR don't give a crap about you

pros: The pay for phlebotomists is decent, and you can experience in phlebotomy. Most of the donors you meet are super nice, and quite a few have become personal friends.
cons: The experience you get as a phlebotomist doesn’t count towards clinical experience. The hours are long, and you get slammed with more work than what you can handle. The upper management doesn’t care about you, and regional management would rather have someone who spreads lies and rumors about staff- as a supervisor. There is no opportunity for job growth unless you’re a nurse, and even then it’s few and far in between. This is an extremely toxic work environment to be avoided at all costs.

review_title: Worst place I have worked at

pros: The pay isn’t so bad

job_title: Donor Care Specialist III in Highlands Ranch, CO
pros:
-Can make a mostly livable income
-Always opportunities for overtime
-The best coworkers
-Matched 401k up to 5% your first year
-Health insurance is alright
-Up to $5,000 of tuition a year towards approved schools in related fields (medical and science)
cons:
If you want to be over worked, under paid and never appreciated Vitalant is perfect. If you want to work for an uncaring and huge company who asks you to live and work with integrity but cannot have an ounce of it themselves, then come work for Vitalant. Constantly hiring new phlebotomists under a veil of lies saying that you will have a work life balance, good pay, great benefits, and possible growth. If you like being yelled at by belligerent strangers, cussed at, and threatened, then this is the place for you. Vitalant will not do anything about it, but rather let them re-book their appointment! If you don't mind never getting breaks on 12+ hour days, missing lunch breaks, putting the safety of people at risk and working for management that tell you after a 14 hour day where you sprinted the whole time while trying to get every donor thought that, "you didn't do enough", then come work at Vitalant. If you want to be viewed as entirely disposable and to hate your life and your job right out of training, this might be the perfect fit. If you want entirely useless management that doesn't give a flying fu@k about you, then go work for the management at Vitalant because they sure don't. 

I have been at Vitalant for 15 months and have not only had terrifying moments, but it has brought on havoc in my personal life because of the lack of flexibility and work life balance. 5 months ago I had to start antidepressants for the first time ever because of the pressure at work I had become so internally depressed. 

I have never seen such burnout in a company than I do at Vitalant. The turn over rate every year is horrifying. Seriously think twice before working here.

pros: Not a bad place to work
cons: Comp increases aren’t as frequent and as much as they should be

job_title: Donor Recruitment Representative in Vaughan, ON
pros: knowing you are saving lives every day is the best feeling. Good leadership . Pay and raises happen quickly. If you want to move up quickly just having a good attitude will get you there.

job_title: Assistant Donor Care Supervisor in Newmarket, ON

But I was constantly pulled in for mertings because the manager felt i had slighted her over a misunderstanding. And she never would let it go. Tgey dont give anyone tools to be successful, and any mention of forming a union will make an employee disappear. They look for any and every reason to get rid of someone instead of a reason to keep them. VERY high turnover rate. BEWARE. You were warned!!!

Hours worked in a week typically range from 45-50. Schedules don't come out in a timely manner and switching shifts with someone is nearly impossible unless management likes you. There is little room for upward mobility within the company. Blood drives are often disorganized, leading to stress on part of staff and donors.

job_title: Med Tech II in Tempe, AZ
pros: Essential service, Feel good about helping people and saving lives. If you want to work lots of hours and can be flexible with hours demanded and changing schedules, this job is great. cons: Chronic short staff. Broken and incomplete work stations. Disorganized work flow. Reactive not proactive management style. Mandatory overtime leading to high turnover and staff burnout. High pressure and unrealistic production quotas for staffing levels. Health insurance benefits are the worst I have ever had. Extreme staff turnover due to uncompetitive compensation.

pros: No experience needed, relaxed work environment
cons: The most monotonous job I've ever worked. Very little room for advancement. I was hired through a temp agency and thus was not entitled to Holiday pay. Permanent workers made about 40 per hour on holidays while temp made the same. At least they're getting rid of temp workers and hiring everyone as permanent workers.

pros: They teach you a lot about your job and help develop those skills

cons: Postdoctoral researcher are not seen as valuable or crucial personnel.

review_title: If you're serious about your career, stay away
pros:
I feel comfortable in my position because most of the staffs I work around with are incompetent. 
Meeting interesting donors and share in their reason to donate.
cons:
Unprofessional management that appears to value you but in reality you are just there to fill a number. 
Any feedback regarding improvements or issues often times just goes into a loop where it eventually disappears. 
Turn over for frontline staffs are extremely high. Most leave within a few months because compensation is well below market rate and scheduling is beyond unreasonable. Vitalant can't even retain staffs around during Covid where job opportunities are scarce elsewhere. Imagine if it was normal time. Most of staff I spoke to before they left, mentioned this a sweat shop disguise as blood banking. 
Unless your career is at the tail end of the it's life and you want a job to ease into retirement, you really should rethink your decision to working here.
They hide behind their propaganda of saying we are here to save lives, when what they really meant is you are working on Thanksgiving and Christmas.

job_title: Donor Outreach Coordinator in Spokane, WA
pros: The people, the technology and the view
cons: The boss, time off, the discipline is not fair.

job_title: Donor Outreach Coordinator in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good people work here, good help
cons: Pay is a little low

pros:
Salary
Benefits
Clear policy and procedure
Staff
On call
cons: Schedule, Management, Change, Locations, Human Resources

pros:
Have a great manager and get to learn new skills in my field.  Love working with my team.  Pay is very good with opportunity for bonus. Great work/life balance.  

Good 401k with matching.  Telecommuting is available.
cons:
Health insurance is just OK.  Aetna does not have the best customer service.  It's in-network only with a fairly high deductible.  The company funded HRA does help with that but still higher deductible than I've had at other companies.  Doctors visits and prescriptions are all paid at full price out of pocket until the deductible is met.  

No short-term disability insurance. There is an in-house illness/injury accrual benefit but it accrues slowly and has to be replenished over time if used.  

PTO accrual is OK.  Paid out at termination.  

If you have a spouse with great benefits it will help.

review_title: Welcoming company, if you're thinking about a change
pros: I am very pleased with my decision to join Vitalant. This company has a culture that is welcoming and inclusive. From the interviewing process to on-boarding and beyond, all processes were streamlined and efficient. Response rates to emails and questions were quick and thorough and it made the process of moving to a new company, after many years, very easy. Vitalant truly values their employees and treats them with respect. Changing jobs is never easy, but choosing to move to a company that has a well organized process, engages/values their staff and embraces a culture of diversity and inclusion makes the decision both easy and rewarding, personally and professionally.
cons: I have not encountered any negative situations to comment on

review_title: Not the best place for growth potential.
pros: There are some very nice people who work here. This company also has a low tolerance for employees who do not follow the RITE values of the organization.  The benefits package is better than some other organizations.
cons:
Some positions do not have opportunity for growth within the position or outside of the position. There are many dead end jobs here.

Exeutive Management is also kept in the dark about issues with major projects.

review_title: Oppressive, 1950's style of top down executive management.
pros: Good pay, some good employees, several good managers. Good company mission.
cons: Stagnant leadership that rules top down without seeking input from staff. CIO that constantly pushes staff without any recognition, praise or respect.  Blatant favoritism goes unchecked Little  accountability of managers makes for a toxic work environment. Lack of long term opportunities and CIO micromanagement that focuses on non-value added activities..  Siloed departments that don't work well together on projects. Long term executives (not all) that take a simplistic view of the amount of work that staff can accomplish without burning out.

pros: None.  Nothing positive to write about
cons: The place is a terrible place to work. Mismanaged and poorly run. The company is in losses and trying to cut corners in everything. Severely under resources and the VP makes release commitments without checking with the QA team. This is the only company that I know that care more about their software vendor then their employees. Employees are underpaid and overworked and expected to work evenings and weekend. Not asked but expected. The VP seems to be in cahoots with the vendor probably some corrupt practices going on. The Director is clueless and blindly follows the VP. CTO is a absolute buffoon. Terrible benefits and time off policies. They force to use your PTO for day after thanksgiving!!! Terrible place avoid at all costs.

review_title: Used to be a "Family" environment but has fallen to the level of cut throat "for profit" organizations
pros: People are wonderful and have a true dedication to the Mission.  They will give as much as it takes.  Unfortunately lately if takes a lot more with a lot less.
cons: There are not a lot of promotional opportunities.  For the higher level postions that do become open, it is evident that people have already been selected to fill them.

pros: Inspiring work that truly makes a difference and saves lives.  New market style food service provides healthier and fresher  food choices in the break room. Excellent health care benefits, competitive pay, great coworkers.
cons: Always short staffed, expected to cover night shifts for staff shortages and vacations without fair compensation. Little chance for career advancement in production environment. Continuing education not encouraged.

review_title: Used to be a great company.... pity!
job_title: Worked At Corporate Office in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: The benefits are great.  The mission is worthwhile and the people are wonderful.  Training was top notch and thorough.
cons: Reorganizations, layoffs, and uncertainty!  There was a "changing of the guard" and many key positions retired.  Now several new high level executives are making sweeping changes.  The focus is less on community and making a difference and more on profits and take overs of other blood banks.

pros: My co-workers, Heath saving account (NOT the health insurance).
cons: Lots of inconveniences for those of us who used to work at ITXM and were taken over by Vitalant.   Before we had local IT people available to help us.  Now we have to call Arizona to talk to an IT person who, if it anything more difficult than unlocking a program, generally cannot help you and has to write a ticket to the "desktop" people -- who are our original IT people!  So instead of taking one phone call to fix it now takes at least 2 calls and having to wait anywhere from 1-4 hours for a desktop person to call back.  My machine died a couple of months ago and it took 3 days to get me a new one.  They won't even allow IT to come to us to set up our machines.  They deliver machines through inter-office courier, you are required to get all the cables plugged in correctly yourself, and then get to call AZ back to get another ticket written to the Dekstop team to call you about things that are wrong (like no printer set up, no Adobe, etc.).  All in all, I spent 3 working days wandering from free desk to free desk trying to find a place to work.  That was very cost effective.  New purchasing system now too time consuming.  If what you want is not in their storefront shops, it is on you to find what you want, find out the cost, hope the vendor is an approved vendor, then complete the purchase req and submit it.  That is all stuff our old purchasing agents used to do but -- oh yes -- they were all laid off. So many, many things wrong, including being brought in under their "new employee" pay scale instead of the pay scale that would represent the number of years you have actually worked in your job even though we were told we were going to be grandfathered into their system..

review_title: Easy work, but flawed culture leads to stress, anxiety, and unhappiness.
job_title: Mobile Account Coordinator in Spokane, WA
pros: Easy hours and solid pay for an entry level position. The MAC position is capped at 40 hours per week with no overtime, so burnout is easier to avoid. The work itself is not demanding, the emails/texting/calling can be tedious but that’s just part of working in donor recruitment and I didn’t hate it. For the most part, the team in the office is friendly and welcoming and makes most days a pleasurable experience. You’ll get to travel a lot around Eastern Washington and North Idaho which was mostly enjoyable.
cons: The biggest con is a culture that is, quite honestly, disappointing. Management offered little in the way of motivation outside of “hey guys, our numbers need to be better”. We were coached constantly on being proactive, but subject to constant last second changes and failures due to lack of preparation from management and the team. Success is rarely, if ever celebrated. Had a good day and met goal? You’ll get a 5 second shoutout in the huddle tomorrow morning. That’s it. Additional complaints would include poor communication from management and between departments, as well as a staggering amount of micromanagement. My supervisor made me document every. Minute. Of. My. Day. No lie. I had to keep excruciatingly detailed notes on how I spent my office day for “efficiency purposes”, only to never receive feedback of any kind on my efficiency or work, essentially making those notes a colossal waste of time that could’ve been spent doing something actually productive. All told, quitting was the best decision I could’ve made.

job_title: Donor Outreach Coordinator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Many experienced Donor Outreach Coordinators. Mgmt treats staff very well.  Positive attitude.  Employees are very dedicated and motivated to bring in blood donations.  This a non-profit  with very good benefits and run professionally. Training is well done and they do not require previous call center experience.  There is no age discrimination.
cons: Starting pay is on the low side.  It is primarily outbound and you spent 85% of your time leaving messages on voice mail.

pros: There are some great people working at Blood Systems corporate office and in the centers and they are all about saving lives.
cons: Short sighted management is more focused on reaction instead of planning. Business decisions leave us scratching our heads and wondering if we'll be the next ones RIFFED.

review_title: YOU ARE A BODY, NOT A PERSON!
pros: We draw blood (that's sold) for the hospital.
cons: The company (BSI/ BONFILS) is more focused on money than its facade of "values". No one cares about the donor or recipient, they just want blood to sell to bolster their salary and bonuses. They are SEVERELY understaffed (down 50+ employees just in CO), forcing employees to drive all over the state and work 60+ hours/week.

review_title: WAS a great entry level healthcare job
job_title: Donor Outreach Coordinator II in Mather Field, CA
pros: Entry level, steady hours, not a whole bunch else...
cons: After Bloodsource became Vitalant everything went downhill. Everything has become very corporate, very goal driven, you start to feel very detached to the "saving peoples lives"  part of the job,  extremely repetitive, Donors hate the change as well they hang up on us constantly, feel like we are sucking them dry and pushing them to donate way too often.

pros: A very small amount of good employees who can turn into lifelong friends. The mission and aspect of the job is amazing but the company it’s self only cares about number. Not the mental or physical health of employees
cons: “It’s not our fault you decided to have kids”.  A quote by a former vitalant manager.  I know this is in the past but is still the attitude the directors/management/recruitment all have. They will call you a few hours before you clock in while you are still in a slumber to tell you to come pick up the bus earlier then they had scheduled you.  Oh and if you say you can’t get ready for a massive amount of attitude or a guilt trip of the century.  This companies standards are not based on how your work performance is, cuz you and everybody else and their moms will get an annual 2.5% raise.  Perfect for all your hard work right??  All the overtime you work on a consistent basis.  But those who don’t perform to the expectations still walk away with the same exact raise as you, the hard working employee. If you’ve never seen FMLA being used, this company has roughly 60-80% of the staff on it.  Some for other medical conditions but a lot for depression and anxiety and stress that the company places on their shoulders.  When the director decides to make a new work policy (use Facebook as a form of identification for the donors) the director will not own up to the falsely given information and put it onto our shoulders.  Favoritism is key here.  Kiss booty or don’t expect to get anywhere.  And by anywhere there’s only 2 positions you can rise up to.  Or 1 cuz the company only wants to promote from outside the company instead of within.  Promotions aren’t about how hard you work for it.  It’s about the person you hear telling jokes and laughing in managements office is who gets it.  Don’t bother speaking at all or you might get under HR investigations.  Let’s not forget.  ANYONE can get this job.  As long as you graduated high school.  If you fail training they will still pass you so it doesn’t cost the company money and affect the turnover rate.  The company has been going downhill for years, and puts the blame on the mobile staff instead of looking in the mirror and seeing who the true culprit is.  At this rate, this company will not be around for much longer.   Or look to sell out.

pros: The work was enjoyable. Liked the experience.
cons: They hire you with no certification. When i moved to nights they always attacked me every morning. Saying that i was slow. I made a lot of mistakes. They compared me to everone else and made me look like the worst employee. Dont bother asking them for reference. They will say that it "goes against our policy" which is absurd. Management doesnt consider any problems with the company. Problems and complaints overlooked. They will tell you you can go against the rules like them but they wont get caught and you will.

review_title: Growing  faster than management can handle.
pros: No lay offs steady work.
cons: Growing  pains  need more staff and  management  really does not  want to hear truth .   Problem brought to upper management.  Management  tells emplyee you just handle it. No guidence.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: None.  RUN AS FAST AS POSSIBLE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
cons: Supervisor always tired and grouchy. Not a team environment unless you have been there years. Constant political talk and bashing of the president of the United States of America. Does not explain anything just does it. While I was was suppose to be trained or observed I was not. I was running instruments alone. I was never trained on an entire block of expectations. I was told I was performing good by most techs and should be signed off on etc etc.  I was told by QC manger training is usually a 6 month ordeal then management said because of my previous experience I should have completed this all within 90 days. Whenever I would come in I was sent straight to the flow room alone no supervision, I would run flow NOT SIGNED OFF for 1st shift. NO TRAINING AT ALL NO FEEDBACK except from one tech. This is not the future of stem cell therapy. The techs take shortcuts. Tell you to do something a certain way then do it a totally different way. Watched techs forge other techs initials. Techs do not know the difference between immature neutrophils and lymphs. Compared to the the hematology analyzer everyone was way off by over 20.  I was told I was under performing and due to my previous experience I should be excelling. One of the areas I was never trained on, the other area  I was fully competent  (told I was not competent but if you go back and look at all the flow sheets I ran them!), and the third area I had roughly 5 times to do. Whenever someone was too busy I was sent into a corner to read SOP's for hours while the other tech talked about her sexual conquests.

review_title: I worked in here for a couple of years

pros: Family oriented company. Takes care of their own. People are long termers.  They tend to stay a very long time.

pros: Great Supervisor, good benefits. There were a lot of very nice people working there. There were many people there that had worked 25 years or more. I early retired to spend more time with my wife.
